text: and there we have it .
the 2014 nobel prize in physics awarded for the invention of blue leds - which allow for energy efficient white lighting .
we 'd expected an experimental theme this year after the 2013 prize went for theoretical work on mass generation in particle physics .
this year 's prize surely sits at the other end of the spectrum of understanding and - for now , at least - practical applications .
join us again tomorrow at 10am uk for the announcement of the 2014 nobel prize in chemistry .

there is no nobel prize for maths although one could argue that physics is essentially applied mathematics , which makes today 's nobels of most interest to the mathematical community .
and speaking of maths , alex bellos 's blog post today is about neil sloane , the samuel johnson of numbers .
he runs the online encyclopedia of integer sequences , a site much used by physicists .
in case you are wondering when the other nobel prizes are announced , my colleague rebecca davis has produced the definitive guide .

my colleague alex hern on the guardian tech desk has this to say on the prize : the invention of the blue led was the final key to using light-emitting diodes low power , long-lasting sources of light in a panoply of different ways , which revolutionised countless technology sectors .
the nobel assembly itself focuses on the importance of blue leds to creating fully white light .
white light is made from combining light from every other colour , but before blue leds , one crucial part of the spectrum was missing .
now , by combining a blue , red and green led , we can create even white light .

you 'll recognise it from the glow of your smartphone screen , where the low heat output and slim size of leds are a selling point , or from the backlight of a newer led tv , where the low power usage lets manufacturers trumpet cheaper electricity bills .
increasingly , white led lamps are replacing other sources of light .
in the home , for instance , led bulbs are becoming a popular alternative to traditional cfc low power ' bulbs .
they use even less power , and last even longer , than the old-style bulbs , can reach full brightness immediately , and are frequently even programmable to display different hues of light .

i struggled to hear nakamura over that bad line between stockholm and santa barbara , but ap is reporting his response as amazing and unbelievable : the laureates triggered a transformation of lighting technology when they produced bright blue light from semiconductors in the 1990s , something scientists had struggled with for decades , the nobel committee said .
using the blue light , led lamps emitting white light could be created in a new way .
as about one fourth of world electricity consumption is used for lighting purposes , the leds contribute to saving the earth 's resources , ' the committee said .
nakamura , who spoke to reporters in stockholm over a crackling telephone line after being woken up by the phone call from the prize jury , said it was an amazing , and unbelievable feeling .

documents.title: they succeeded where everyone else failed
text: here 's more from the nobel committee on the science and its implications : when isamu akasaki , hiroshi amano and shuji nakamura produced bright blue light beams from their semiconductors in the early 1990s , they triggered a fundamental transformation of lighting technology .
red and green diodes had been around for a long time but without blue light , white lamps could not be created .
despite considerable efforts , both in the scientific community and in industry , the blue led had remained a challenge for three decades .
they succeeded where everyone else had failed .
akasaki worked together with amano at the university of nagoya , while nakamura was employed at nichia chemicals , a small company in tokushima .
their inventions were revolutionary .
incandescent light bulbs lit the 20th century ; the 21st century will be lit by led lamps .
white led lamps emit a bright white light , are long-lasting and energy-efficient .
they are constantly improved , getting more efficient with higher luminous flux ( measured in lumen ) per unit electrical input power ( measured in watt ) .
the most recent record is just over 300 lm/w , which can be compared to 16 for regular light bulbs and close to 70 for fluorescent lamps .
as about one fourth of world electricity consumption is used for lighting purposes , the leds contribute to saving the earth 's resources .
materials consumption is also diminished as leds last up to 100,000 hours , compared to 1,000 for incandescent bulbs and 10,000 hours for fluorescent lights .

the led lamp holds great promise for increasing the quality of life for over 1.5bn people around the world who lack access to electricity grids : due to low power requirements it can be powered by cheap local solar power .

in the spirit of alfred nobel the prize rewards an invention of greatest benefit to mankind ; using blue leds , white light can be created in a new way .
with the advent of led lamps we now have more long-lasting and more efficient alternatives to older light sources .

and here we go
if it was n't for the economics prize , the physics prize would be the most male-dominated of all .
only two women have won the physics prize .
only one has been awarded the economics prize .
bear in mind though that the economics prize has only been going since the late 1960s .
the physics prize was the first nobel mentioned in his will - it 's been there from the start in 1901 .
the nobel assembly has done away with the music they used to play on their webcast while we waited for the announcement .
a missed opportunity really : they could have dropped hints in through their choices of tunes .
the committee should emerge from its discussions in five to ten minutes .
but we 've had delays before , not least last year 's one hour wait .
there was plenty of controversy over the 2013 prize to francois englert and peter higgs .

though both were undoubtedly first and second respectively to publish on the mass-giving mechanism linked to the higgs boson in 1964 , a group of three other physicists gerry guralnik , richard hagen and tom kibble developed the same theory independently within a month or two .
the harsh and fairly arbitrary nobel rule of the prize going to no more than three people meant they were excluded from the honours .
the nobel assembly has totted up the winners by field .
the dominance of particle physics owes in large part to the flurry of particle discoveries in the 60s and 70s .

last year 's prize followed experimental confirmation of the higgs boson at the large hadron collider , but the prize went for theoretical work in the 1960s that described how some fundamental particles acquire mass .

documents.title: what the pundits say
text: once again thomson reuters has totted up citations to scientists ' work and come up with a list of potential winners .
they are going for charles l kane , laurens w molenkamp and shoucheng zhang for their work on the quantum spin hall effect and topological insulators .
also in with a chance are james f scott , ramamoorthy ramesh and yoshinori tokura for research on ferroelectic memory devices and multiferroic materials .
another name from them is peidong yang for work including the creation of the first nanowire nanolaser .
but plenty more names are in the running .
after last year 's prize for theoretical work , my money ( had i any ) is on an experimental breakthrough .
i 'd love to see john pendry at imperial college win for his extraordinary work on metamaterials ( though invisibility cloaks sounds better ) .
or anton zeilinger for his work on quantum entanglement .
and so to the 2014 nobel prize in physics .
the nobel assembly will announce the winner or winners from stockholm today at 10.45am uk time or soon thereafter .

yesterday we learned the recipients of the medicine prize : a basketball-shooting professor at ucl in london and his two former postdocs who , now married , work at the norwegian university of science and technology in trondheim .
they discovered nerve cells that , according to the nobel citation , constitute a positioning system in the brain .
tomorrow it 's the turn of the chemistry prize .
the awards are worth 8 million swedish kronor ( â£ 690,000 ) apiece .
but back to today and the physics prize .
if you ever wondered who had done most to unveil how the world works , you could do worse than pore over the list of physics laureates .
the names are stellar : the curies , becquerel , planck , the braggs , einstein , bohr , heisenberg , schroedinger , dirac , fermi , pauli .
the list goes on , with prizes for the inventors of wireless telephony , the transistor and ccds used in digital cameras .
it culminates with last year 's much-anticipated prize for peter higgs and francois englert for their theoretical work in the 1960s that described how elementary particles acquire mass .
( that announcement was delayed after peter higgs went awol . )
since 1901 the nobel assembly has awarded 107 physics prizes .
of the 195 scientists to receive the prize , only two have been women : marie curie in 1903 for work on radiation and maria goeppert-mayer in 1963 for her work on nuclear structure .
